annotations.text: Threat group Evilnum has been observed using Commonly Used Port to compromise systems.
The malware PowerSploit implements Commonly Used Port (T1043) to evade detection.
The malware BloodHound implements Plist Modification (T1547.011) to evade detection.
The malware Tasklist implements Plist Modification (T1547.011) to evade detection.
The malware Pacu implements At (Linux) (T1053.001) to evade detection.
The malware SILENTTRINITY implements Login Item (T1162) to evade detection.
Security teams detected BlackByte using Plist Modification and applied Login Item Mitigation as countermeasure.
Security teams detected menuPass using JamPlus and applied Vulnerability Scanning as countermeasure.
The malware Bumblebee implements Indicator Blocking (T1562.006) to evade detection.
Security teams detected Dragonfly using MMC and applied Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription Mitigation as countermeasure.
Threat group APT3 has been observed using MMC to compromise systems.
The malware ngrok implements System Script Proxy Execution (T1216) to evade detection.
The malware Amadey implements System Script Proxy Execution (T1216) to evade detection.
Threat group Night Dragon has been observed using Netsh Helper DLL to compromise systems.
Threat group EXOTIC LILY has been observed using Firmware Corruption to compromise systems.
The malware BloodHound implements Firmware Corruption (T1495) to evade detection.
Threat group APT38 has been observed using Dynamic-link Library Injection to compromise systems.
The malware Lslsass implements LSASS Driver (T1547.008) to evade detection.
The malware Amadey implements Pass the Hash (T1550.002) to evade detection.
Threat group APT38 has been observed using Re-opened Applications to compromise systems.
The malware at implements Space after Filename (T1036.006) to evade detection.
Security teams detected menuPass using Space after Filename and applied Network Intrusion Prevention as countermeasure.
The malware ipconfig implements Software Packing (T1027.002) to evade detection.

Software Packing (T1027.002) is a technique where Adversaries may perform software packing or virtual machine software protection to conceal their code. This can be mitigated using Audio Capture Mitigation.
The malware certutil implements Access Token Manipulation (T1134) to evade detection.
Threat group APT3 has been observed using Server Software Component to compromise systems.
The malware Pacu implements Server Software Component (T1505) to evade detection.
The malware PowerSploit implements Clear Persistence (T1070.009) to evade detection.
Security teams detected NEODYMIUM using Clear Persistence and applied Setuid and Setgid Mitigation as countermeasure.
Security teams detected Evilnum using Screensaver and applied Data from Information Repositories Mitigation as countermeasure.

Screensaver (T1546.002) is a technique where Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity. This can be mitigated using Password Filter DLL Mitigation.

AppInit DLLs (T1546.010) is a technique where Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by AppInit DLLs loaded into processes. This can be mitigated using Exploitation for Credential Access Mitigation.
Threat group Evilnum has been observed using AppInit DLLs to compromise systems.
Security teams detected NEODYMIUM using Data Encoding and applied Scheduled Transfer Mitigation as countermeasure.
The malware Net implements Domain Fronting (T1090.004) to evade detection.
Threat group TA577 has been observed using Domain Fronting to compromise systems.
MSBuild (T1127.001) is a technique where Adversaries may use MSBuild to proxy execution of code through a trusted Windows utility. This can be mitigated using Compiled HTML File Mitigation.
Threat group Evilnum has been observed using MSBuild to compromise systems.
Threat group Evilnum has been observed using BITS Jobs to compromise systems.
The malware Impacket implements Domain Accounts (T1078.002) to evade detection.
Security teams detected Evilnum using Startup Items and applied Binary Padding Mitigation as countermeasure.

Component Object Model Hijacking (T1546.015) is a technique where Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by hijacked references to Component Object Model (COM) objects. This can be mitigated using Space after Filename Mitigation.

Component Object Model Hijacking (T1546.015) is a technique where Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by hijacked references to Component Object Model (COM) objects. This can be mitigated using Hidden Users Mitigation.
Threat group BlackByte has been observed using Regsvr32 to compromise systems.
Threat group SideCopy has been observed using Regsvr32 to compromise systems.
Threat group TA577 has been observed using Authentication Package to compromise systems.
Authentication Package (T1547.002) is a technique where Adversaries may abuse authentication packages to execute DLLs when the system boots. This can be mitigated using Audio Capture Mitigation.
Threat group SideCopy has been observed using Elevated Execution with Prompt to compromise systems.
The malware Exaramel for Windows implements Elevated Execution with Prompt (T1548.004) to evade detection.
Security teams detected Volt Typhoon using Network Boundary Bridging and applied Hidden Users Mitigation as countermeasure.
Threat group Gorgon Group has been observed using Network Boundary Bridging to compromise systems.

Resource Forking (T1564.009) is a technique where Adversaries may abuse resource forks to hide malicious code or executables to evade detection and bypass security applications. This can be mitigated using Regsvr32 Mitigation.

Resource Forking (T1564.009) is a technique where Adversaries may abuse resource forks to hide malicious code or executables to evade detection and bypass security applications. This can be mitigated using Regsvr32 Mitigation.
The malware JumbledPath implements Indicator Removal from Tools (T1027.005) to evade detection.

Data from Network Shared Drive (T1039) is a technique where Adversaries may search network shares on computers they have compromised to find files of interest. This can be mitigated using Credentials in Files Mitigation.

Network Share Connection Removal (T1070.005) is a technique where Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation. This can be mitigated using Peripheral Device Discovery Mitigation.
The malware Net implements Network Share Connection Removal (T1070.005) to evade detection.

Services File Permissions Weakness (T1574.010) is a technique where Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the binaries used by services. This can be mitigated using Data from Information Repositories Mitigation.
The malware PowerSploit implements Emond (T1546.014) to evade detection.

Emond (T1546.014) is a technique where Adversaries may gain persistence and elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by the Event Monitor Daemon (emond). This can be mitigated using Peripheral Device Discovery Mitigation.
Threat group Salt Typhoon has been observed using Parent PID Spoofing to compromise systems.

Network Device CLI (T1059.008) is a technique where Adversaries may abuse scripting or built-in command line interpreters (CLI) on network devices to execute malicious command and payloads. This can be mitigated using Password Filter DLL Mitigation.
The malware Windows Credential Editor implements Video Capture (T1125) to evade detection.
Threat group APT17 has been observed using Video Capture to compromise systems.
Security teams detected GALLIUM using Setuid and Setgid and applied Compiled HTML File Mitigation as countermeasure.

Setuid and Setgid (T1548.001) is a technique where An adversary may abuse configurations where an application has the setuid or setgid bits set in order to get code running in a different (and possibly more privileged) userâ€™s context. This can be mitigated using Regsvr32 Mitigation.

Create Process with Token (T1134.002) is a technique where Adversaries may create a new process with an existing token to escalate privileges and bypass access controls. This can be mitigated using Hidden Users Mitigation.

File and Directory Permissions Modification (T1222) is a technique where Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files.(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls1 June 2018)(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls2 May 2018) File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. This can be mitigated using Space after Filename Mitigation.

File and Directory Permissions Modification (T1222) is a technique where Adversaries may modify file or directory permissions/attributes to evade access control lists (ACLs) and access protected files.(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls1 June 2018)(Citation: Hybrid Analysis Icacls2 May 2018) File and directory permissions are commonly managed by ACLs configured by the file or directory owner, or users with the appropriate permissions. This can be mitigated using Scheduled Transfer Mitigation.
The malware Impacket implements Binary Padding (T1027.001) to evade detection.
The malware AcidRain implements Binary Padding (T1027.001) to evade detection.
Security teams detected Night Dragon using Disable Windows Event Logging and applied Hidden Users Mitigation as countermeasure.

Disable Windows Event Logging (T1562.002) is a technique where Adversaries may disable Windows event logging to limit data that can be leveraged for detections and audits. This can be mitigated using Gatekeeper Bypass Mitigation.

Process Injection (T1055) is a technique where Adversaries may inject code into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. This can be mitigated using Data Destruction Mitigation.
Threat group Night Dragon has been observed using Process Injection to compromise systems.
Security teams detected NEODYMIUM using Clear Network Connection History and Configurations and applied File System Permissions Weakness Mitigation as countermeasure.

Clear Network Connection History and Configurations (T1070.007) is a technique where Adversaries may clear or remove evidence of malicious network connections in order to clean up traces of their operations. This can be mitigated using AppInit DLLs Mitigation.
Threat group APT3 has been observed using Msiexec to compromise systems.
